description.title: Welcome Home
description.text1: Welcome to our apartment, a cozy retreat completely renovated in the heart of Paris. Nestled in a 17th-century building, it has kept all its period charm: exposed wooden beams, stone walls, and that special atmosphere of old Parisian buildings.
description.text2: Located on Rue François Miron, one of Paris' oldest streets, you'll be in the heart of Le Marais with its unique neighborhood life. Boutiques, cafés, restaurants, art galleries... everything is within walking distance.
description.text3: Saint-Paul metro station (line 1) is 200 meters away and provides direct access to the Champs-Élysées, the Louvre, and Bastille.

notes.title: Good to Know
items: The main hallway is narrow, typical of period buildings in Le Marais.
The apartment is on the 2nd floor without an elevator.

neighborhood.title: Le Marais

francoisMiron.title: François Miron
francoisMiron.text1: The street where our apartment is located bears the name of François Miron, provost of merchants of Paris from 1604 to 1609 — the equivalent of the mayor of Paris under the Ancien Régime.
francoisMiron.text2: Nicknamed 'the father of the people' by his contemporaries, he was a close associate of King Henri IV and devoted his personal fortune to the beautification of Paris.
francoisMiron.text3: He is credited with the façade of the Hôtel de Ville, the first Samaritaine (water pump near the Louvre), and the renovation of Parisian aqueducts.

street.title: The Street
street.text1: Rue François Miron is one of the oldest streets in Paris. It follows the route of a 2nd-century Roman road that connected Lutetia (Paris) to Melun and Sens.
street.text2: Renamed in 1865 by Louis-Philippe in honor of the provost, it houses medieval half-timbered houses (nos. 11 and 13), among the last in Paris, dating from the 14th century.
street.text3: The building housing our apartment dates from the 17th century, with its characteristic exposed beams and stone walls.

marais.title: Le Marais
marais.text1: Its name comes from the marshes that occupied this area until the 12th century. Drained by monks, the neighborhood became in the 17th century the residence of Parisian nobility.
marais.text2: Spared from Haussmann's 19th-century renovations, it retains its medieval architecture and private mansions, many of which have become museums.
marais.text3: Today, it is a vibrant and cosmopolitan neighborhood: LGBTQ+ community, historic Jewish quarter, art galleries, designer boutiques, and lively nightlife.
